top_comment.text:
Paying for an education seems weird to me. - A knowledgeable/skilled 
population means a healthy country, and is the driving force of the 
economy. - I have two bachelors degrees, and it didn't cost me a penny 
except living cost/rent, which I paid for by working at the local gas 
station on weekends and evenings.

I went on to do a 6 months unpaid internship, got a job, worked there for 8 
years, and now have my own business. - It was lucky, but also the school 
system enabled me to jump on the opportunities being presented.

Being 50 000 ++ in debt after finishing the education would have been 
disastrous.﻿

+BrooklynBiggis There are really very few occupations that, by their 
nature, require degrees and certificates. Engineering and medicine are just 
two of those few that require a degree. You could easily apply for an 
internship at local businesses, including hospitals, game studios, and even 
factories. The only point of college these days is to get experience in the 
field at a low cost. If you want to go into the CG movie or video game 
industry, the software that is predominately used in the industry will cost 
hundreds for a single seat license. Comparatively, for my college (it's a 
community college), I'm only paying $50 per credit hour in classes 
(although it can also be either $100 or $150 depending on residency). That 
means, for an entire semester, for someone who lives in the district served 
by the college, they could enroll in four classes, and get the books for 
less than $2000.

comments.text:
No, it is you who is the idiot, because you dont read, but argue with 
emotions. The law says that a purchased item has to work and the buyer has 
to pay for the item. The law also says that an educator has to educate and 
the student has to pay for the education. Period! Whats so difficult to 
understand you fool?
The law places an onus to the seller for the item to work. and the law 
places an onus on the educator to give education. Nothing more and nothing 
less. The law doesnt say that the educator must guarantee a job. The law 
also doesnt say that the educator must give the student numbers on 
placements, just as the law doesnt say that the buyer of the item must be 
satisfied with the item (Remember the term "buyers remorse" in high 
school?). Thats outside regulated law. Principle and philosophy of the law 
is always to seek a compromise between contractual parties.
The law doesnt want to favor the seller. And the law also doesnt want to 
favour the buyer. The law has additional consumer protection laws, but on 
the question of colleges and job placement figures there are no consumer 
protection laws (Thank the Bushes and Obamas you voted for). So therefore 
common contractual law strikes a compromise: The seller has to provide the 
item in a functioning state (how? Thats not the buyers problem --> thats 
the problem of the seller). But if the item is delivered and it doesnt suit 
the buyer, then thats not the sellers problem --> thats the problem of the 
buyer).
And if the student placement nonsense is  outside of regulated law and 
outside of the contractual agreement, then the student should have paused 
and said: "Hhhm, wait a minute... Can I have that in writing, sir?" They 
didnt. They got tricked on their ignorance and you are on the best way of 
following in their footsteps by getting tricked on your emotional 
stupidity, you dunce fool.
Now get the fuck outta here, you intellectual lightweight. Discussing with 
a Youtube fool who has no clue what the fuck he`s talking about is just a 
waste of time, you fucking retarded idiot.

top_comment.text:
A beautiful illustration of why the idea of a "mixed" economy is actually 
not that sensible. Businesses are designed to make a profit. And no, that's 
not "greed"; making a profit is the whole point of a business.

If it's possible to make or change a law to benefit your business, then of 
course that's what you're gonna do. Because otherwise, your competitor is 
going to do it and you're gonna lose.

What people fail to understand is that the system selects the kind of 
person that's going to get in a position of power.

For instance, currently our system favors greedy sociopaths to become heads 
of corporations. That's because corporations are fictitious, monstrous 
legal entities that are diametrically opposed to the concept of a free 
market. So people without conscience tend to be more successful in those 
positions.

Thus, the idea of adding more and more laws and regulations to control the 
market is unfortunately completely doomed to fail. The market is what 
generates wealth; wealth leads to power, power influences the law. 
Therefore, the law is never going to keep the market in check as people 
intend and hope for.

Here's what needs to happen: capitalism has to be seperated from the state 
just as religion once was.
There shouldn't be such a thing as "business law". Laws should apply to 
real individuals who can be responsible for their actions, not fictitious 
entities.

The more you merge the market with the state, the more dangerous and 
dominant a system it will result in (- >fascism). Seperate them, and it 
becomes a harmless system that actually serves the people (- >free market).

Just to be clear: As long as capitalism and state law influence one 
another, a free market is completely *impossible*.﻿
top_comment.author: Alexander Reiswich
